name: Fair-Testing
tagline: Devising a fair system of trials: The online lab book
body:
##Getting Started

### To Get Hold of the The Fair Testing Repository
```
git clone https://github.com/thisMagpie/fair-testing
cd fair-testing
git fetch origin
git checkout master
```

### To Run Java Project

```
cd fair-testing/java
javac *.java
```

###Run Project

```
java RunTest
```

## Compile The Latex Standalone Graphs

```
cd fair-testing/java/output
pdflatex output-datafile.tex
```

## Introduction to This Project

The project aim is to answer the question of whether university examination procedures are fair by testing the accepted hypothesis set put by the Edinburgh University Taught Assessment Regulations against physical exam data of students in the School of Physics and Astronomy at the University to see if the university model works enough to support the assertion that a 2% standard deviation on a student classification has any reliable, reproducible basis in reality.

## Introduction to This Page

This page provides a general summary of the relevant points noted during email and meeting discussions between Prof. Graeme Ackland and Magdalen Berns about the project.

The site also also provides the reference material compiled over the course of the project and links to the relevant pages which combine to form the project lab book in digital form.

The decision to present the lab book as a website is purely to aid convenient reading and to preserve the chronological project notebook protocol at the same time with less clutter in the way of the most important information taken down over the course of the project.

Commit logs and associated activity graphs are accessible via this landing page too. These contain date stamped changes which are possible to check via git diff using the gh-pages branch.

That includes the commit history (and messages) for the codes as well as the notes wiki and reading list are also available to view via this website. 

#Initial Test Parameters

## Gaussian One: Student Ability

This Gaussian assumes the student is capable of achieving 60% within a standard deviation of 22.6%. The error estimate made is not fully justified. There is a real possibility the student will fail so this estimate for the standard deviation is likely to be too low when compared with the actual physical data available.

However, the system is trialing the exam scores of a population of students from the Edinburgh University School of Physics and Astronomy, which is [Ranked No. 17 in the world](http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/world-university-rankings/2013#sorting=rank+region=+country=+faculty=+stars=false+search=) and follows a syllabus which is standardized to conform to the Institute of Physics criteria for accredited British Physics degrees  hence it is expected that a University which only allows the very strongest physics applicants of the world onto to study will in turn find a greater number of student achieve the very highest grades of the country at the end of their degree.

To simplify matters. This Study will only look at those courses which are part of a physics degree accredited by the [Institute of Physics](http://www.iop.org/). This will allow a qualitative assessment of the results in context of the county pass fail progression rate at the end of the study.

 * mean: 60%
 * std deviation 22.6%

###Gaussian two: Test Difficulty

 * mean: 60%
 * std deviation 2%

# Exam Data

###[Stellar Evolution](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Stellar%20Evolution-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1372244111000&api=v2)
 * Number of students present in the exam: 18
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 16

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 61%
 
### [Astrophysics 3 Exam](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Astrophysics%203%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1372243932000&api=v2) (Scaled Up by 3%)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 37
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 29

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam) : 48%

NOTE: The grade was scaled by an average of 3% to raise the class average to 51%

### [Electromagnetism Exam](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Electromagnetism%202013%20-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1371462797000&api=v2) 

 * Number of students present in the exam: 84
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 68

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 57.31%

### [Advanced Statistical Physics](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Advanced%20Stat%20Phys-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1371477108000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 17
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 17

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 72.35%

###[Quantum Mechanics](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Quantum%20Mechanics%202012-13%20S1%20-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1371462818000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 82
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 73

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 59.16%

###[Dynamics and Relativity](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Dynamics%20and%20Relativity%202012%20-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1358775761000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 70
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 61

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 63%

###[Lagrangian Dynamics](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Lagrangian%20Dynamics%202012-13%20S2%20-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1371462795000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 63
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 63

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 63.41%

###[Physical Mathematics](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Physical%20Mathematics%202012-13%20-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1372246724000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 87
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 67

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 67.9%

An interesting contrast to Lagrangian Dynamics which has a lower average grade yet a 100% pass for all students who sat.

###[Statistical Mechanics](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Statistical%20Mechanics%202012-13%20S2%20-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1371462818000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 86
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 72

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 63.47%

###[Symmetries of Classical Mechanics](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Symmetries%20of%20Classical%20Mechanics%202012-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1358775762000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 35
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 31

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 57.1%


###[Thermodynamics](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Thermodynamics%202012-13%20SV1%20-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1371462818000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 69
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 68

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 68.5%

###[Statistical Physics](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Statistical%20Physics-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1371477305000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 77
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 70

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 65.17%

###[Relativistic Quantum Field Theory](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/RQFT-%20wiki.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1371477294000&api=v2)

 * Number of students present in the exam: 23
 * Number of students who passed the exam: 17

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 47%

###[Physics Skills BSc](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Physics%20Skills%20-%20BScM4M5%20201213.pdf?version=2&modificationDate=1371477265000&api=v2)

Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 57%

###[Physics Skills MPhys4](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Physics%20Skills%20-%20BScM4M5%20201213.pdf?version=2&modificationDate=1371477265000&api=v2)
Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 61%

###[Physics Skills MPhys5](https://www.wiki.ed.ac.uk/download/attachments/135806883/Physics%20Skills%20-%20BScM4M5%20201213.pdf?version=2&modificationDate=1371477265000&api=v2)
Average mark of the course (includes only those students who sat the exam): 63%

Note: Physics Skills results indicate that there is a larger std deviation in Exam difficulty than previously predicted.

#### [Reading List](https://github.com/thisMagpie/fair-testing/wiki/Reading-List)

A general reading list containing relevant (and not so relevant) books, papers, API Documentation, lecture materials, data sources and websites sourced over the course of the project but which may not end up being directly cited in the final thesis itself.
